Despite some minor short comings, I find the latest installment in the Halo series to be every bit as fun as its predecessors.  No, the graphics aren't as good as Gears of War.  Sometimes the voice acting is a little hard to hear.  The storyline gets a little convoluted, but I don't care.  I was a little disappointed to see that the graphics are only marginally better than Halo 2, but I don't care.  Once I started playing I totally enjoyed myself.  The gameplay is still engrossing, challenging, and just plain fun.  I will say that the Flood looks much more detailed and interesting than in the past.  I really like some of the new vehicles (especially the chopper).  Most of the weapons are the same, but that doesn't really detract from the game.  If you like Halo, I don't see why you wouldn't like this installment.
overall, its fun and feels like the show. but gets very boring fast. Very short game and leaves nothing to do after beating it.

description: Batman: Arkham Origins features an expanded Gotham City and introduces an original prequel storyline set several years before the events of Batman: Arkham Asylum and Batman: Arkham City, the first two critically acclaimed games of the franchise; Taking place before the rise of Gotham City's most dangerous criminals, the game showcases a young and unrefined Batman as he faces a defining moment in his early career as a crime fighter that sets his path to becoming the Dark Knight; As the story unfolds, players will meet many important characters for the first time and forge key relationships
summary: Not quite what I was expecting (pleasantly surprised)
reviewText: The first two Batman games were nothing short of amazing. I was definitely buying Arkham Origins, regardless of the things I was hearing and reading about it. I'll admit that my expectations were lowered due to the fact that a different group made the game. However, might I be so bold as to say this is the best Batman game I've ever played? Lets find out.Combat - It's pretty much the same combat system as before, which will always be a good thing in my book. Some have argued the combat feels a bit 'stiff', but I didn't notice that. The only difference that kind of stood out is the difficulty of some of the fights. I really looked forward to fighting huge groups of enemies in Arkham Asylum and Arkham City because it became easy once I got the hang of things. Arkham Origins' fights are lengthy and difficult, and at times feel like a total button masher. I'll explain what I mean: I've played more than my fair share of action games on the PS3. There's only been two games that caused me to experience forearm fatigue because of the button mashing fighting. Those games are Heavenly Sword (demo version) and now Arkham Origins. This is a prequel, so perhaps the fighting is difficult because they're wanting to emphasize that Batman is early on in his career, I don't know. At any rate, it gets a little easier when you acquire a certain gadget that I'll discuss in the next paragraph.Weaponry - If you've played any of the previous Batman games, you'll know he mainly uses gadgets as opposed to weapons, and that trend continues. The usual gadgets are present, so I'll focus on the new additions. We all know about the remote controlled batarangs; well now there's a remote controlled batclaw! Awesome, right? It doesn't really directly affect combat, I mainly used it to connect to far away grapple points. The concussion detonator actually does affect combat. It'll cause enemies to be momentarily dazed, giving you the chance to move in and put in work! The glue grenade is used to shut off those ever so annoying steam valves (or you can use the grenades on enemies too). Now to my favorite addition - The shock gloves!!! Here's how they work: You build up the battery by pounding on bad guys. Once fully charged, each melee strike will be accompanied by an electric shock. This made the tougher combat more enjoyable and a little easier :-)Enemies - I noticed a few new enemy types sprinkled here and there. The ones that stood out were the ninjas, the dudes with the venom filled canisters on their backs, and the brutes. The ninjas were different because you'll have to plan your strikes against them, as opposed to straight button mashing. I've been hearing a lot of negative things about the boss battles, and I don't understand why. In my opinion, each one was a little different and required some technique. Ok, the first one was a button mashing affair, but the others really weren't. You probably recall me saying I've played several PS3 action type games. Well, the final boss battle is the most terrifying boss battle I've ever encountered!  I'm tempted to explain why, but I can't do so without giving spoilers. Some people are smart enough to give details without spoiling the game, but I'm sure in the hell not...Miscellaneous - Don't worry guys and gals, there's plenty of sidemissons with some pretty cool enemy encounters. You will not see the usual Riddler puzzles (thank God), but there are still collectables around town. Also, you'll get an opportunity to solve crimes, similar to how it's done in LA Noir, if you're familiar with that game. If you're into multiplayer, that feature is available in a Batman game for the first time. Arkham Origins didn't feel quite as long as the others, but it took me about 28 hours to complete (that includes the sidemissions and me screwing around in the city).The only negative thing about the game is very minor, but I still thought I'd mention it. The graphics are not as good as the previous two games, but that's not a big deal to me. After finishing Arkham Origins, I felt it was the best Batman game I've ever played. I had tons of fun, and was constantly looking forward to what might happen next. I'll be honest, if you play this game and you don't think it's at least 4 stars, I'll be shocked. Ratchet & Clank: Into the Nexus, you're up next!

description: Normally, Nintendo contract players such as Mario, Pikachu, Link, Donkey  Kong, Bowser, and Kirby are generally happy and well-mannered, but inSuper  Smash Bros. Melee, the pleasantries get thrown out and the gloves (except  for Mario's) come off. This update of the N64 favorite features these and other  video game icons in furious, yet utterly absurd fisticuffs that usually make for  a smashing good time. Just make sure you have at least one human opponent to  pound on.Starting off with 14 characters (an additional 11 are waiting to be unlocked),  the game has a pretty standard premise--let Nintendo's stars beat on each other  until the timer runs out. However, a lot of emphasis is put on knocking  opponents off ledges while avoiding the same fate. In typical Nintendo manner,  there are quite a few power-ups to assist you in the melee. The actual combat  isn't as intricate as in other fighting games; however, the ultra-cartoony  layout of the many, many arenas sometimes adds a strategic element not usually  found in similar titles.Super Smash Bros. Melee's strength lays in the mayhem created in  four-player fights. The camera does an excellent job of positioning itself so all  combatants are constantly visible. Also,Meleesports some of the best  visuals seen in a Nintendo product. All the characters are highly detailed, and  the movements of each are smoothly infused with personality. Donkey Kong lumbers  and Princess Peach fights with grace.As the multiplayer mode is the key reason for this game's existence, the  single-player mode is decidedly weak. The game features an adventure mode that plays  somewhat like an old-school, side-scrolling Mario game. Sadly, despite its good  looks, its gameplay is rather uninspired. This game is clearly at its best when  there are two or more players with controllers in their hands.--Mark  BrooksPros:Fantastic graphics and sound keep the action upbeatMany new characters and other goodies to unlockCons:Single-player experience is comparatively weakToo cute for a few folksAdventure mode is boring

Back in 1997 when the Nintendo 64 was enjoying success, Star Fox 64 was one of the must have titles.  It had some of the best graphics you could find, some exciting gameplay and was--then--one of the few video games to utilize voice acting.  Almost everything about the experience was new and different.  In this day and age certain aspects don't hold up as well.  On the other hand, the game itself is still fun.  It's not quite as amazing as it was in 1997, but it's still a lot of fun.Star Fox 64 isn't really much for story.  Aside from the opening crawl there isn't really a whole lot of story.  All you need to know is that Andross has declared war on the Lylat system and it's up to team Star Fox to stop him by flying across the galaxy to his homeworld of venom to put an end to his plans.  The game has around fifteen different levels but you'll only play through seven of them.  Two of them will always be the same.  No matter what you'll begin in Corneria and end in Venom.The basics of play haven't really changed at all.  Star Fox is an on-rails shooter where you'll cruise through the levels shooting at other flying enemies that get in your way.  You can charge your laser for more powerful shots, fire bombs and perform certain maneuvers such as doing barrel rolls to deflect shots, performing somersaults to dodge certain enemies or use the boost to get through certain obstacles.  For the most part, if you played the game on the Nintendo 64 nothing has changed on a gameplay level.Star Fox 64 is a short game.  There's no getting around that.  The game can easily be bested in a single sitting.  Thanks to the branching paths through the main campaign, however, there's some replay value here.  Most of the levels have certain tasks you can perform to go down different paths.  For example, in the first mission if you save Falco while he's being chased and then show him some smooth flying by flying under the arches on the water you'll go down a completely different path.  If you find any particular level too challenging the game will allow to change course.  Those who play well and showcase some of their chops will travel down a harder path.  Those who struggle too much get taken down an easier path.  Most of the levels are short and snappy, but they don't always come without challenge.  Some stages are busy throwing quite a bit at you.  One moment you're soaring through Corneria the next you're in an asteroid field dodging those... and then you find yourself on Solar where your Arwing is constantly taking heat damage.For the most part there isn't much out there quite like Star Fox 64 because you don't find that many games on rails in quite the same manner anymore.  This gives it a unique feel, but it hasn't really changed a whole lot from the N64 version released so long ago.  The game plays and feels exactly the same.  You won't find places populated by new enemies or anything strangely out of the ordinary.  It's pretty much an exact port.That's not to say there are no tweaks.  The most obvious is the graphical enhancement.  It stays true to the art style but many of the games stages have noticeably more detail.  But it sticks so well to the art style that those who haven't played the game in a long time would swear it ALWAYS looked like this.  It didn't.  Just looking at the water on Corneria alone or looking at the map of the Lylat system shows some noticeable changes in the graphics.  Everything is smoother and prettier.  The voices have also been re-recorded.  You may notice a line or two altered but some of the most familiar lines ("Do a barrel roll!") have stayed the same.  The soundtrack has also been remastered.  It's still familiar in every way it's just been updated.The biggest addition to the game are without a doubt the Gyro-Controls.  You can move and tilt your 3DS to control your Arwing.  This sounds good in theory, but in execution you'll forget about it after a while--the novel wears off.  The classic way to play is the way to go.  Using the circle pad and face buttons is just all around easier.  Especially because the Gyro-Controls are sensitive.  The slightest tilt of your 3DS will cause your Arwing to respond in kind and this makes certain moments more challenging than they have to be.  If you insist in playing the game withe the 3D on then the Gyro-Controls will only cause everything to be fuzzy thanks to your constant movements.The multiplayer isn't really much to write home about, however.  It's cool that your picture will pop up and all, but there isn't much to the multiplayer experience.  You can't go online (and even if you could I'm sure you'd have to deal with Nintendo's awful friend code system) and unless you've got some friends to play with it isn't engaging.  You'll quickly forget about the multiplayer at some point and jump right back into the main campaign.For those who enjoyed the game way back on the Nintendo 64 nostalgia alone is powerful enough to make it worth looking into.  For those who have never tried it before, it's worth taking a look into because the game still plays rather well even today, in part because there just aren't that many games out there like it.  It's on the short side but it has a lot of replay value and at the end of the day it's just fun.

I haven't played any other Fear games and so this might explain why the plot was completely lost on me. Two brothers brought up in a sterile experimental facility observed at play, at sleep and at war. Okay got that. For some reason though one of them doesn't talk and both boys really don't look alike at all. I'd like to see the milkman as I'm pretty sure we're looking at two different dads here. But regardless of the confusing fable presented in Fear 3, no good game's success should fall on the shoulders of the story being told however lackluster it may be. I mean, did we really care who the Space Invaders were? Nahh.So what you have is a solid FPS. Not really much variety of weaponry, and since you can only carry two weapons at a time it makes sense to have a long range and a short range with you and the shotgun and three-burst semi do the job thorough out the game nicely. There's slow-mo bullet time fodder which isn't nearly as satisfying as I expected as most bad guys take loads of rounds and in some cases many reloads to fall and often don't drop before bullet time has drained. For example there's a particular type of glowing blue bad guy that even in the game's easiest setting, Recruit, takes an inordinate amount of lead to drop. It does get kind of old at times.The atmosphere is obviously something worked on long on hard by the devs and there's at least a couple of truly spine-tingling moments in Fear. Usually these scares weren't so much from the 'BOO!' gotchas but more from some naturally creepy surroundings and audio that have been nicely constructed to induce suitable 'wet my pants' moments.Each chapter, or interval, usually is based around a particular location; supermarket, airport, broken bridge etc although later chapters are much shorter than earlier ones and this resulted in a quick wrap-up feel to the game especially the final boss battle.One factor I do like is once done, you can begin the game from the point of view of Fettel the more vocal of the two brothers. Without spoiling things, Fettel's abilities are more supernatural than Point Man's and add a really refreshing slant to a subsequent play through. The single player campaign also has an RPG element with rewards such as extra health or new abilities being awarded based on your performance and those stats are carried through from one play through to the next. Anything that gives more replayability should be applauded.Obviously the game has been also heavily tuned for co-op which unfortunately along with MP I did not play. No matter though as I felt I got more than enough game out of the single player mode and despite there being little new here I enjoyed the game for what it is.

reviewText: I tried to get into the old tomb raider games but ive never enjoyed the heroine. I just can't get behind a character who is a stereotype.  Scantily clad females with with inhuman proportions really don't hold my interest in a gaming environment. This new take on the Croft character is a breath of fresh air. She is more life like and real,  she shows weakness and vulnerability.  All too often the characters in games are almost godlike and superhuman. And while to some degree they have to be,  it's nice to see a character that is truly in danger and best of all she knows it.The gameplay is steller. Platforming has never been more fluid... I especially like the rock climbing portions. It seems fast, fluid, and responsive. Nothing like the old tomb raider games. It's also very open,  not linear like Uncharted. Alot of the collectibles are found by experimenting with the terrain and seeing where you can climb next.  The gunplay is accurate, naturally weighted, and visceral... I love the new archery fad in these next gen games. Everything feels polished and awesome. This game takes what worked in uncharted and captilizes on it. But uncharted did the same with the old tomb raiders so all is fair.Last the story because the graphics are obviously good. The story fits alot like a toned down lord of the flies or heart of darkness origin for the enemies and our heroione just happens to be caught in the middle of it. Well shipwrecked. I really enjoy all the collectable journals each one revealing more about the dark history of the island you're now exploring.

summary: "Go and Save Yourself. And Take it out on me." - "TOMB RAIDER (2013)" Review (SPOILERS)
reviewText: INTRO:Since "The Angel of Darkness", the cultural icon known as "Tomb Raider" has struggled to find its balance and place in an era where platforming and puzzle games have become Unicorns in the video game franchise. More importantly, "Tomb Raider" has struggled to resemble some form of a competent game. The Lady Lara Croft appeared to have done just in 2006 with Crystal Dynamics and the release of "Tomb Raider Legend". As an action platformer and puzzle game, "Legend" was one of the best "Tomb Raider" experiences I've had since I played the original game back in 2001 when I first got a PlayStation 2 for Christmas. I can say the same of "Anniversary" and "Underworld" as well.Yet, with the jaded community who's followed Lara Croft through every evolution of her character's history --- be it through comics, movies or the dismal video games that followed after "Tomb Raider III" pre-Dynamics, it simply wasn't enough. And for whatever reason, after the less than stellar success of "Tomb Raider Underworld", Crystal Dynamics went to back to the drawing board with Lara.But instead of addressing their own follies in regards to writing and game mechanics, their philosophy with the announcement of a reboot of "Tomb Raider", was that the problem lie with Lara Croft herself and not so much their inability to deliver a decent product. Riding on the coattails of the "grimdark" fad that was seemingly sparked with Christopher Nolan's "Batman Begins" in 2005, Crystal Dynamic's aim was not only make Lara Croft "human", but put her through the ringer by placing emphasis on physical and mental torture of what it would take to survive on a seemingly deserted island.At first glance there's not much wrong with that premise; it seems like a solid idea overall, but further contemplation raises the question of "why" exactly the train of thought today's world is that in order for an audience to connect with a character, they have to be emotionally and physically tortured.Secondly, the only real problem Lara Croft truly suffered as a character was the mere fact that she was often promoted to be an object (and that she was stuck in a series of bad games). You could never really say Lara Croft experienced the same respect in the media as Ridley Scott and James Cameron's Ellen Ripley for breaking the preconceived notions of what a female character could be or do. Sexual objectification is a large part of what makes Lara Croft an "icon" in the media; there isn't a promotional photograph from the "golden days" where Lara wasn't posing for the camera in ways that were specifically catering to the male gaze (and to add insult to injury there was a "Nude Raider" mod created, further pinpointing her role as "ionic" character based solely on her assets). And then there were the "Croft Babes", models created to sell the game to the massive during premieres or conventions. Yet, despite all of that, for a lot of gamers (more importantly, to a lot of gamers who happen to be female) the character's strengths lies more with her independence and strength borne out of the fact that she could tango with the wackiest enemies --- animal, male, female, supernatural --- and was never thought of anything less than "action girl". Sure, her character was about as deep as James Bond (and if I have to be specific, Movie!Bond), but a "weak" character is something you could never call Lara Croft. She was a hardboiled character with the noir of Max Payne and a smart mouth with a doctorate no less.Thus, when Crystal Dynamic's primary advertisement seemed more aimed at passive-aggressively knocking Lara Croft as she was and declaring "New Croft" was somehow a revolutionary take on a character who suffered but a few minor problems connected to sexism and bad writing, I had to wonder whether or not we were seeing the same character and playing the same game. The biggest compliment I could probably give them is recreating the character to suit the physicality of real woman's body as opposed to continually catering to the 3D Doll-esque model as they've done in the last three games under their tenure. Outside of that, their promotion of the game and the narrative the game itself speaks more to the points they keep on missing than anything that progresses "Tomb Raider" forward.GAMEPLAY:"Tomb Raider" is, at best, an "Uncharted" clone with the worst of Ubisoft's "Far Cry 3" RPG and hunting elements--- aka busywork at best, grinding at worst. It brings nothing new to the table as a game and sparks revolution in nothing. If were talking game changers here, there's nothing "Resident Evil 4" or "Gears of War" about it. If I could call "Tomb Raider" anything in regards to its mechanics, it's the "Halo 4" of franchise; inoffensive, but enjoyable. Everything, to how Lara travels through the environment, how she finds artifacts and narrates (a feeble way of reminding the audience "she's an archaeologist, see?") down to how the world is built around Lara's actions screams of Naughty Dog influence, who in turn were inspired by "Tomb Raider", "Prince of Persia" and "Indiana Jones", only they do it better than the pioneer herself. The environmental puzzles, while fun when you can figure them out, are a pain in the rear end when you can't.As per the usual with games of these types, I found myself getting frustrated for merely over complicating what was arguably a insultingly simple puzzle (merry-go-round cargo cages, and the temple puzzles that utilized the wind) to the point of rage quit. To the best of my knowledge, "Tomb Raider" doesn't use that one helpful tool in "Uncharted" known as "Press R2 for a bloody obvious Hint". Why can't puzzles be a nice blend of enjoyable and challenging like they were in "Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time"? I might've gotten equally frustrated, but for whatever reason, I never felt like I was being judged for missing obvious points when I finally succeeded and squealed with elation (seriously, screw that "Well" level before the "Baths" level, but reaching the top and being greeted by a horde of Blue Sand Monster types was the greatest feeling in the world). As far as puzzles go, they're by no means challenging... unless you're like me who thinks the developers put that much thought into it and I go the extremely long way around figuring it out. Their a blend of zip-line, explosive and use arrow to hook movable object. They feel mandatory, but not something that naturally fits with the environment or the gameplay.Animal hunting is probably something I went out of my way to avoid when the game didn't require it and it usually didn't after the tutorial. Not only does it trivialize the disembowelment of animal for an almost useless mechanic that never holds any bearing narratively, it's just badly done. A quick swipe at an animal and you've got a screen full of stale jelly and useless experience points. If they really wanted to make this mechanic make sense, they should've take a page out of Jasper Byrne's "Lone Survivor" and made it a necessity that Lara hunt for food and water under the threat of starving to death; otherwise it's unnecessary, just like the whole skill point/tree itself. Crystal Dynamics also decides to take a page out of Visceral Games' "Dead Space" and gleefully puts Lara Croft through the ringer of some truly gruesome death sequences that not only break the atmosphere of the game, but raise the question of whether or not they missed the point with Visceral's "so-over-the-top-its-hilarious" montage of death altogether. Sure, the game has its typical fall to your death then cut to back scenes, but they're far outnumbered by the aforementioned. There are death scenes then there's fetishism with killing a character on the phallic symbols of the world presented in game.The biggest negative I can speak of, really, is the lack of choices in regards to how approach the enemies. The game sells itself wholly on the concept of "survival", but it only gives you a sole option on how to "survive" the ordeal on the island. Never is there a time where you can simply evade or be urged to run from the crazed islanders when they outnumber you or otherwise, instead your only option is use the ice axe, gun and handful of dirt against them in combat. Combat, basically, is your only option when dealing with survival.The stealth elements in this regard, are wasted. Stealth is merely an extension of combat; sneaking up behind enemies allows you to kill them silently, but just as soon as someone notices their missing --- well, get your gun ready, you're in for a fight. And from there it's all matter of how much your patience can deal with killing your opponents as "Tomb Raider" offers nothing new in the respect of "Mortal Kombat"-esque deaths without the parody levels of gore and decapitation. Enemies barely allow you to recover or breathe once they've found you and it's a half-n-half of challenging and downright bothersome. If I thought throwing my controller at the screen could KO an enemy I would probably do it at the risk of my screen's life.Enemies later faced in the game, "The Storm Guard", are a re-skinned version of the heavy armored enemies (and the "Guardians" practically lifted from "Uncharted 2") and they're no more fun to kill than they were when they were guys with riot shields. On top of that, the game never translates Lara's inexperience with weapons or combat into the gameplay itself, primarily concerned with catering to the gamer(s) who don't want to be faced with the challenge of dealing with, say, the trembling arms of a young girl who's never handled a pistol or a machine gun when she's knocked back from the recoil. If they had integrate RPG-elements into the game, then its focus should've been on improving Lara as a efficient combatant or stealth operative as opposed to focusing on the weapons. Show us that Lara is inexperienced and afraid instead of fitting the game with the tried and true combat mechanics that will work to their advantage, but to the detriment of the story. A sort of "panic/inexperience mode" that progressively lessens the better she gets with weaponry or evasion.Quick Time Events suck; in an age where these things are becoming more and more of intrusion, robbing the player of any control, "Tomb Raider" could've done with a lot less QTE. There's not much more to it that, they suck.So, does all of the above make it a bad game? No, far from it; "Tomb Raider", is actually pretty fun mechanically speaking. The illusion of an open world invites the player to grouse around environments that aren't teeming with enemies and take in the world with specific intention of being admired by a playing or viewing audience. The best time I probably had was creating ziplines and going down ziplines, especially the bit wherein I had jump across a network of them to get down to the beach level. Crystal Dynamic's biggest problem with "Tomb Raider" games post "Legend" is that they were never willing innovate or spruce up problems they created and thus fell into a rut. While "Tomb Raider" is a mere rehash of familiar gameplay from experiences that offered them in far better games, it's nice to see that they finally did something about the combat FINALLY. So while this sounds like I didn't have a good time with the mechanics, there's not much to say about the parts I enjoyed other than "I had fun".STORY:Rhianna Pratchett doesn't exactly have the greatest track record in regards to her screenplays for video games. "Heavenly Sword's" narrative as equally as frustrating as its overly-tight and unresponsive mechanics/controls; her patch work quilting of "Mirror's Edge" doesn't beholden her much in any way either. The narrative in both were so equally irrelevant that it's easy to dismiss them when both games primary concern were with its gameplay and not its story. Here is a different tale altogether. Here, they want you to care about these characters; they want to be a human drama piece cobbled around a video game. It's the entire reason why they've supposedly gone this direction as opposed simply making a "Tomb Raider" game with better mechanics and a little more thought in its plot.To say nothing of Crystal Dynamic's announcing the writer as a means to deflect their poor advertisement of the game as "protection simulator", "we're not sexist, the writer's a female" and "oh, that's not an attempted rape scene, you're just seeing things", Rhianna and Crystal Dynamics attempt to deal with an issue that neither really understand or try to. The game truly tries to make a grand statement on the issue of survival --- being pushed into a corner and clawing your way out to safety, but its intentions fall flatter than bread rising.Lara Croft's "transformation" in the character Dynamics so badly wanted to steer her away from is not only forced, it never feels genuine. In fact, the character development (or lack thereof) runs at the pace of a movie set for 90s minutes only and I've seen 90 minute movies handle character development better than this game does. To say nothing of the action-vs.-story elements that never match up with each other, the narrative has characters make grandiose statements about survival and sacrifice, but none of it translates. It all feels like something Rihanna read off a cue card, a few articles about surviving impossible situations and PTSD and never quite digested the enormity of the meaning behind harrowing ordeals like the one they put Lara through. Unlike the "Sam gets captured" scene that's been removed in favor of Lara merely blacking out in the presence of a person she clearly doesn't and shouldn't trust, the attempted rape scene still exists and it's still used as the starting point of "Lara will become stronger because of this", but it's not a natural progression, especially for a game that literally skips all introductions of characters and sets up the game with the bloody teaser trailer from 2011 with some sequences chopped out.By the time Lara starts being snappish at her crewmates and behaving as if she knows how to survive better than the lot of them (when they're pretty much even the scale of "still alive"), it's pretty game breaking and speaks of Pratchett's laziness in regards to development. The storyline never once saddles the player with the consequences of the actions of the cult or the actions of Lara; there is no remorse on Lara's part for taking lives (the game practically glorifies her execution styled kill moves and combat in general, however optional), however "justified" she may be. She more or less becomes one of the crazed cultists herself, spouting angry lines more befitted to Kurt Russell in "Tombstone" because the situation there gave you a reason, an example as why Wyatt Earp would declare himself the pale rider of the Revelations. Here, Lara doesn't and isn't given that reason, not one that works anyway. Moreover, it just wrecks the experience.The "Apocalyptic Log", messages left about by various inhabitants of the island about the supernatural power of a Japanese Queen/Priestess preventing them from escape, doesn't do much to lend atmosphere to the game. What's more, one left behind Lara's crew raises the question "when did they find the time to find a pencil and write a last will and testament?" It worked in "Dead Space", because the audio logs are presumably auto-recorded by the character's RIG (the green thing on their backs) and text logs were written then characters are in hiding or before stuff hit the fan. "Tomb Raider" disregards situational necessities like this and goes "whatever". Even worse, there's a moment with the Obi-Wan Kenobi of the game leaves a letter he had no time to write and declares Lara "the daughter he never had" despite the fact that he has a daughter with Joslin Reyes, one the crewmen that accompanied him, and their interaction with each other doesn't imply they kept secrets from each other and Joslin's back story pretty much confirms he knows he has a daughter.And while we're on it, the characters in the game are forgettable. Like Lara, no development is afforded to any of them and the game is completely comfortable with forgetting they exist. There were times where I couldn't tell one survivor from the other unless they were speaking with an accent or had garish yellow, green or blue subtitles to signify their character. Roth is a pretty bland character who exists only pep talks that suffer from greeting card mentality; when he dies they pretty much ruin the entire moment with a disembodied pep talk from the grave and then Lara repeating what "he might've said" to her if he were still alive. The only thing missing at that point was a glowing blue ghost. Jonah Maiava is the obligatory "magical Kiwi" who "senses" something's wrong with the island and provides Lara with a new bow (and that's really about it); Joslin Reyes is the cop turned mechanic who provides little to nothing to the story beyond "fall in line or we leave you, Lara" (fine with me, really); Samantha and Alex are the obligatory damsels in distress for Lara to rescue (Samantha contains the one pet-peeve I can't stand: people calling other people "sweetie"); Angus Grimaldi is "Cookie" Farnsworth from "Atlantis: The Lost Empire"; and the archaeologist James Whitman does a poor service as an unintentional villain in any respect of that field; he's so clumsily inserted into the narrative as an antagonist that I often wonder if his infrequent appearances were a result of being a character added at the last minute.The villains, the crazy cultists are no more convincing as characters than they are as a threat. The antagonist, bad guy with a hood #10823 (I can't remember his name), poses no more of a threat to the player or Lara as a character than Katherine Marlowe in "Uncharted 3", only he lacks her presence. Either way, he's just as easy to kill.Another irk I've with the story is that it places so much emphasis on Lara's father, Richard Croft (Lord Croft, whatever his name is in this canon) and as usual the mother is all but forgotten outside of being the reason Lara even exists in an in-universe perspective. This is a major disappointment after "Legend" and "Underworld" placed so much importance of the disappearance and relationship Lara had with her mother, Amelia Croft. Basically, I'm tired of mothers being shoved off to the side and the fathers being praised like their the only element in a child's life that matters.To sum it all up, "Tomb Raider's" story is bad. In retrospect, it's bad like "Fary Cry 3" is bad. It's writers try to tackle a subject that neither have no real understanding or respect from within either gameplay or narrative perspective. A big name with a famous father does little to help its credibility. It's just another rotten rung in the long line of bad stories presented by Lara Croft.PRESENTATION:Visually speaking the game is a hit-or-miss. The environments, to be sure, are gorgeous. In fact, if I were a betting man, I'd say most of the development team's efforts went into the creation of the world around Lara and not so much Lara and her companions. As it is, the in-game cinematics presenting the characters in motion is downright reminiscent of Square Enix cinematic pre-PS3 era; sure it looks better than anything a PS2 could process, but the overall presentation of the characters in the game is pretty disappointing when you consider the hardware. Mouths barely move in sync with the voice acting and almost look as if they don't open at all in some instances. Everything on their models are stiff and almost appear to be molded out of clay. Honestly, I think they could've done far better than what they did here with the graphics, character wise. Otherwise, they've won the gold star for environments.Jason Graves' score pales in comparison to Troels Brun Folmann's mammoth score of atmosphere, mood and adventure for "Legend"; the latter composer is sorely missed in this regard as Graves' composition simply sounds like a continuation of his "Dead Space" scores (all three of them). He hits all the same marks --- chaotic melodies, experimental sounds with unconventional instruments, not unlike Brian Reitzell did with "30 Days of Night (2007)" --- and maintains just about the same themes, only instead of violin, the piano is king here in "Tomb Raider". That said, it's not a horrible score it's merely unremarkable, especially when you consider the masterpiece Troels left us with in 2006.Voice acting on the other hand, tends to fall flat and never extends beyond serviceable. Camilla Luddington fails to the carry the game as the voice of Lara Croft; while the character is intentionally made unsure and lacks what a veteran actress like Keeley Hawes might've brought to the table as a mature Lara Croft, even when youth is taken into account, Luddington's green gills as a performer are apparent throughout her performance. It's largely up to the voice actors around her to pick up the slack, yet they're no more remarkable than Luddington herself. Basically, I'm beginning to suspect the forgettable performances here in this game are largely a result of the script and the direction offered. If that's the case, then they should've hired someone on both spectrums who could at least get some kind of memorable performance.The game's audio overall is great; wearing a pair of headphones or simply playing game without them still manages to deliver the strengths of the environment through incidental sounds; the rustling of trees, nearby animals, the crash of water against stone and rushing water in general all service to immerse you in the environments when the story and acting cannot.OVERALL:As far as third-person-shooters with platforming and puzzle elements go, "Tomb Raider" is unremarkable, but it's fun. Mechanically, I could call it a great game. Narratively, it's a awful and insulting; don't tote to want to deliver on themes you can't handle unless you can come correct and do it right. The characters, including Lara herself, are forgettable. Altogether it's a half-n-half of a game you're bound to have fun with. However, as a "Tomb Raider" game --- whose elements were literally borne of the adventure puzzles and platforming and depended on them --- it's a complete failure."Tomb Raider" fans looking for a return to form won't find it here; Dynamics, like every other developer, has pretty much abandoned any kind of focus on 100% puzzle-and-platforming, the only positive in this regard is improved combat. The negative is that the old guard that made "Tomb Raider" what it is is going to be dumped to wayside for some pale imitation of "Uncharted" to placate those who'll play it to focus on the TPS elements. Nevertheless I can recommend this game to those who are looking for a great third person shoot and do so without hesitation. The "Tomb Raider" reboot gets a generous 3 out of 5.

description: Neo-Paris. 2084.Personal memories can now be digitized, bought, sold and traded. The last remnants of privacy and intimacy have been swept away in what appears to be a logical progression of the explosive growth of social networks at the beginning of the 21st century. The citizens themselves have accepted this surveillance society in exchange for the comfort only smart technology can provide. This memory economy gives immense power over society to just a handful of people.Remember Me is a 3rd person action adventure where players take on the role of Nilin, a former elite memory hunter with the ability to break into people's minds and steal or even alter their memories. The authorities, fearful of her knowledge and capabilities have arrested Nilin and wiped her memory clean. After her escape from prison, Nilin sets out on a mission to recover her identity, helped by her last and only friend. This search for her past leads to her being hunted by the very people that created this surveillance society.

summary: You can sneak in or you can take them all out
reviewText: Having only played the original Splinter Cell game years ago, I can't really comment so much on the storyline here. There is a lot going on, and the team members here are completely different from the first game. The franchise has obviously evolved over time. However, the gameplay here is a lot of fun. You are given choices in some missions so you can choose to sneak in and away, or engage the enemy. Other missions, however, have specific goals, and it even goes so far to give you free reign in the beginning (a point to reach however you see fit) and then change the rules when you get there (kill all the enemies in the room). The controls are fairly easy, though there was no noticeable tutorial going in so it took a minute to figure out how to fire the gun rather than just stealth kill. Great cut scenes and graphics, and responsive controls make this a fun way to spend an afternoon.

First let me start off by saying I am a huge fan of all types of video games. Whether they are open world, first person shooter, rpg etc I will play them all. When I first saw Watchdogs premier at E3 oh so long ago I got so excited and was visually convinced by the beautiful graphics and intriguing story/gaming ideas that this was going to be a truly unique gaming adventure. Fast forward into the future and I must say that Watchdogs is not all it is cracked up to be.I don't agree with Ubisoft's decision to downgrade the graphics on the Playstation 3 to 720p  when the machine is fully capable of running games at 1080p. Although the console is technically now proceeded by the Playstation 4 that doesn't mean you shouldn't get the most out of your software.Like other reviews have suggested, if you have played previous Grand Theft Auto titles or Infamous titles then you will be very familiar with the gaming format of Watchdogs. It's truly nothing new your character is put in a "dangerous" situation in which he must escape and this is your first mission and introduction to your  basic "hacking powers".  These include hacking cameras, ATM machines, and cars to name a few.Eventually you will try and evade the authorities (sound familiar) and do so either on foot or in a car that is conveniently provided to you by an associate in a nearby garage (*nudge to GTA).  Oh and it's not that you're a bad driver, the controls in this game aren't a 10 by any means.I shall not give away the rest of the game but essentially you go through missions in a open map world to unravel the story.Taking into account the Story, controls and Graphics I would give Watchdogs a 6 out of 10 on the PS3. It's an average game, and the controls and graphics really let it down on the PS3. If you're going to invest in Watchdogs I would try it on a Next Gen Console or PC.

Players can drop in and out of each other's games at any time with no loss of progress as well as the ability to continue on alone or with others.Withthousands of weapons in-gameto collect, from simple wooden bats to fire-axes to heavy rifles, Dead Island is a collector's dream. This in combination with Dead Island'sweapon customization systemwill enable the player to craft the ultimate weapon to ensure their survival.The ability to enhance and develop your character usingRPG-like elementsincluding an XP/leveling system and un-lockable skill trees put the power in your hands to create and play a unique protagonist.Dead Island's damage system gives an unprecedented visual detail of the effects of each attack on enemies pushing the boundaries of visualized gore.With anopen-world setting, Banoi is filled to the brim with things to do and objectives to tackle, allowing a fresh way to advance both the characters and story at the same time and providing for endless replay value.
summary: It's pretty good, worth the money (now)
reviewText: Sadly I didn't feel like writing a full review of this game, but I mainly just wanted it to be known that the game has been patched tremendously (at least from how early reviews talked about). I haven't encountered one save issue since I've gotten it, and I've beaten it 2 times and then some.The game isn't to be taken for an Oblivion/Fallout-clone-gone-wrong, because it just isn't anything of the likes. It's a rather fantastic, semi-open world free roam, zombie game. The system is wonderful for what the developers had to work with, and it does a good job of executing things. With that being said, it does execute world events (planes flying by / people on speakers/noises) at awkward times, and leaves you wondering either where is that sound coming from or...just plain what?I've seen reviews talk about the zombies as if they were very AI-rrific, hard to kill, and relentless; this is pretty true for the most part. However, once you get the hang of killing them, the excitement of a hardcore 1 vs 1 zombie battle goes away. The only thing that continues, to this day, to kill me are the Infected. In this game, Infected doesn't refer to the entirety of the zombies, but only a type.There are Walkers, Infected, Thugs, Suiciders, Rams, Floaters, and Butchers -- and not to forget Raskol gang members, they aren't zombies, but gun-wielding humans.Walkers are just your average zombie: if they see you, they stumble your way to attack.Infected are...think zombies on steroids. They can see you at great distances, letting out an otherwise terrifying scream letting you KNOW they've spotted you, running -- not stumbling, RUNNING at you, and attacking in 3-hit bursts. It's hard to kill them because they almost purposely circle around you while destroying you, and if you don't know which direction they are hitting you in, you might just go ahead and call yourself dead. (They aren't glitchy, if you gathered that from what I said, they are just too smart and annoying to come across.I'll leave the other zombies for your experience. I can't even remember how long the game is, but it does have replay value. It's a good enough length for such a game, the environments change at just about the same time you start getting tired of the current one, which keeps the game a bit more interesting.Online play is fun, but it gets kinda messy for 2 reasons. The only way to pause the game is if all the players in co-op have also paused the game. An icon will appear in the top left of the screen, a pause indication. That's letting you know that someone paused the game. That's a good thing, however the messy part comes in when you try to actually communicate with another player.If you just randomly joined someone's game, there is no in-game chat system, you either need a Microphone or to add them and open a chat room. Meaning you have to pause the game just to speak, and if no one else pauses the game while you're talking, you're defenseless against zombie attacks. The other reason this gets messy, but also a good thing I suppose, is that you can track any quest you want, regardless of what quests your other partners are tracking.It causes a sense of separation when people just start going where they want, splitting from the rest of the group. And at times, not knowing what quest the other person is tracking. Although, don't get me wrong, there IS a way to check what quest everyone else is tracking, and that's by opening the quest window, and you'll see a player's icon and name next to a quest, that's how you know which they are tracking.Sadly, quite a few (new) players don't know that, so it makes just jumping into a random game and experiencing someone's first time annoying and messy.If it seems like my review is lacking any emotion, it's probably because it is :( like I've said above, I don't feel too much like writing a review! I just figured I'd do so since I re-stumbled across this listing. I might as well just end with pros and cons!PROS*Semi-Open World and Free Roam gameplay. (It's free roam and open world, but you have to zone to different areas of the island, which means load screens, but other than that, it's 100% free roam.)*Being first person and focusing on melee combat might seem weird, but it does a nice job of it, and you never really get tired of using a melee-wep.*The game is QUITE scary when you play alone, it's not as much when you play with someone else though (or maybe it is for some.) Listening to the shouts of zombies in a random direction alerts you that they are gonna start pelting you with attacks soon enough. The scary part comes in when you don't know where they are coming from!*Game is a decent length, and you change environments at the point where the current one gets a little boring. It has decent replay value, and has a current (as of 12/05/11) DLC, and more on the way.*Overall fun, and a good rental if not buy.CONS*Online Co-Op can get very messy and unorganized, which causes the game to become less fun, and loses it's "scare" factor when people are running experiencing stuff without you.*Isn't a game that you can continuously play (is this really a bad thing though?) It starts becoming boring after a certain point, and it's best to just turn it off before you risk just not wanting to play it for a while.There really aren't many cons about the game. Judging it from what this game has, and how well it was executed, it's a really good game. There really isn't much I would change about it. It doesn't leave a lasting impression like "this is my favorite game!" but it's a true zombie killing game, which earns respect in my book.I think that's all I have to say, as I said above, I didn't have that reviewing power for this review, but I hope I covered the basics!

reviewText: The adventure started off very promising as I was thrilled to roam freely on an exotic island then the bugs came along.For starters there are issues with the character getting stuck in walls and even ground (this is much frequent when driving). Occasionally when you get out of a vehicle or press the quick item menu your movement will be restricted to going forward and backward, unable to move side ways or aim. Imagine how fun this is when a horde of zombies is closing in...Then there's the problem of items/weapons disappearing from the quick menu after being killed and respawned. Every time this annoyance occurs you have to hit Select/pause game and re-add your items to the quick menu.And not the last your character decides to switch to using fists instead of your current weapon in use. All these issues are random and kill all the fun.If it wasn't for all these quirks this would have been a solid game for me but surprisingly I managed to get through over 70% of the campaign which as many have pointed out consists of repeating quests (get gas, medicine, food, turn off this, turn off that, bring this, bring that etc).On the plus side graphics and effects are beautifully rendered and the ambient tracks get very engaging when in combat.I wish I could give this five stars as I'm sure the developers and designers meant well but this is alpha quality software that shouldn't have been released until all these major bugs were fixed.

reviewText: The Good: Amazing visuals, voice acting, good story for Resistance fans, solid mechanics that work, fun boss fights, great weapons, addictive multiplayerThe Bad: Long winded campaign that's stretched thin, can be so difficult you'll want to quit, gets boring and repetitive about halfway through, a few broken mechanicsWell before you read this review I've NEVER played any of the PS3 Resistance games. With that said RR is a great game, but is extremely hard and has a few flaws that bring it down quite a bit. While I can say RR is slightly overrated, it's really only for Resistance fans (well and newcomers...kind of). You play as John Grayson who is part of the Marquis (a French resistance army fighting against the alien Chimera horde). While Chimera aren't as cool as Helghast, Locusts, or even Covenant they are pretty damn creepy.One of the first things I have to get out-of-the-way is that RR uses the Syphon Filter engine and, unfortunately, feels a lot like said games. RR plays similar to the SF games, but with tweaked controls and the engine is, of course, updated. You have a new `snap" cover system which means Grayson will duck behind, or snap against, cover and this is both useful and annoying. Sometimes when you wanna quickly get out of cover Grayson will "stick" to the cover exposing you to certain enemies. There is no blind fire so this makes it hard to shoot enemies when you don't have some type of shield (more on those later) since you're completely exposed. Switching weapons is fairly simple since holding down the right D-pad button pauses the game briefly so you can choose your weapon. This allows a tactical advantage and gives you a minute to think.There are a lot of useful weapons in the game, but my favorite is the BM00001 which is a Chimeran weapon that shoots plasma rounds, but secondary fire charges these and they can be bounced around and kill multiple enemies (they home in on the enemy). Charging all 45 rounds can make a super powerful shot and kills up to 3 enemies at once. Another useful weapon is he sniper rifle which slows down time when you zoom in. Another great (and probably the most fun) is the Auger which has a non-movable deployable shield and can shoot through infinite amounts of solid objects AND even shows you enemies through objects. While ammo for the latter two are scarce...that's the downfall of having fun weapons. While the 7-8 weapons are fun you never feel they're enough and you tend to run out of ammo in the wrong situations.Playing on normal I always had too much ammo when enemies were scarce, but the later levels (trust me there's a LOT of later levels) when you have the most powerful of enemies coming after you in swarms you pinching rounds and that's a no-no in shooters. I felt like I was playing a survival horror than a TPS. I never even bothered finishing the whole since 1. The game got to damned frustrating since late in the game too many enemies are thrown at you at once with scarce health and ammo. 2. The game seemed to never end since I was 6 hours into the game and had no idea where the end was. I know the Syphon Filter games were a bit short, but c'mon this is a PORTABLE game; especially when it's as repetitive as it is. You feel you're just wiping out enemy after enemy and this gets boring about half way through. Sure there are some FPS mech sections (they're pretty fun), but a lot of the game is just repetition. Don't get me wrong the game is completely playable, but the last half feels tacked on and stretched thin.The game has great boss fights, cool weapons, good mechanics, and amazing visuals. These are some of the best on the PSP and if you've played SF: Logan's Shadow you'll know what I'm talking about. The game's story is really only for Resistance fans and I know I would have had to have played previous Resistance games to have understood this. The multiplayer however is what keeps you coming back.If you played SF multiplayer you'll know what I'm talking about. The maps are pretty big, there's little lag, and everything's easy to navigate so you can jump right in. Of course you can collect intel like in the SF games, and there are skill points (Ratchet & Clank fans know what these are), but they are really hard to get since you have to just be lucky and do something right. Think of these as Xbox 360 achievements or PS3 Trophies, but without knowing how to get them...yeah kind of dumb. To be honest this whole game is for Resistance fans only, but this is also some of the best portable action you're going to get.Oh by the way: YOU CAN CHANGE THE CONTROL SCHEME!!! Stop whining that the face buttons don't make up for a second analog nub. Switch the scheme so the face buttons allow you to strafe. Ok all done? Yeeesssss now enjoy....
The only complaint I have is that there are some cheap deaths from time to time. Other than that, I think everyone who's enjoyed the series should givethis a try.

Before I begin, let me say that I own Halo 1,2,3, and Reach.  I've even read some of the books.By the time I got to Reach, my love of the franchise had dwindled quite a bit, but I played the hell out of Halo in LAN parties and I really felt I needed Halo CE Anniversary so I could experience some quality nostalgia.I played through the whole campaign, and it's pretty much the same.  Though it would seem there was a plot point added involving a cutscene where Guilty Spark 343 has a conversation with an unidentified construct.  I don't recall that being in the original and If 343 Industries intends to change Halo history, then I'm going to be a tad miffed.  Or should I say, more miffed.I expected this to be a multiplayer gem.  It's not.  First mistake, they didn't remake all the original Halo multiplayer maps, or if they did, they aren't included on the disc.  Second mistake, NONE of the maps are on the disc!  You need a download code which is included, so access to XBL is essential.  Third mistake, not making the consumer aware of this before purchase.I expected this game to have NO fewer features than the original, and I am livid that there are only 6 multiplayer maps available and that they aren't even all from the original Halo.  I feel like I was robbed, and I am expecting 343 Industries to try and sell me the other half of the game VIA DLC.  I will not buy that.  I bought the original, I bought the sequels, and I've had enough.  This idea that you can nickel and dime your customers to death has been played out by EA.  If you're going to pull that crap you need to release the base game for free like Farmville and make your money solely off the DLC.Does the game look nice, yes.  I'll give it that.  It's even kind of neat that you can switch between the 2 game engines.  But even at the most intense moments, the game still seems to suffer from nasty frame rate issues, which is kind of sad because graphically I think they could have made it look better.  Just a hunch, but that limitation is probably caused by the hardware being made to run both engines simultaneously.Also, I realize that it's basically the same single player game that was produced 10 years ago.  But having played so many other games since then, you become aware of just how stupidly repetitive the campaign is.  By the time you're trying to get the index and following 343 around like a lap dog you begin to be so annoyed that you want to shoot yourself in the head.  Which loops back to the main problem.  Halo's saving grace was always the multiplayer.  Releasing this without all the original maps makes this game essentially worthless.  I mean the very LEAST they should have done was port the original maps over without bothering to gussy them up.  Just having those available for online multiplayer would have made it a worthy purchase.  But I guess they settled for the least they could have done instead of the least they should have done.So this is where I part ways with the Halo Franchise.  I'm not giving you another penny.

reviewText: I bought last year's version of NBA 2K and liked in and all but it just didn't have that factor that made me want to come back and keep playing it.  This year is different!  It has Michael Jordan and we get to live 10 of his greatest games!  And who hasn't wanted to play as MJ in a basketball sim?!  As far as the game goes the visual graphics and gameplay have been slightly improved, nothing major but it already looked so it's not like alot needed to be changed.  Something I did see an improvement on was the Defense, on both sides of the ball.  Its easier to keep up with your opponent as opposed to last year where you'd get burned by just reaching in.  And you can say good bye to those easy pick-n-roll buckets because the AI will pick it off most of the time unless its well passed.  Another thing that bothered me about NBA 2K10 that is fixed in this year's game is the user interface.  It was cluttered and just didn't feel right.  It's much better this year and alot more organized.  Overall this is a well executed game.  You can tell the dev's put alot of effort this year.  Don't hesistate and pick this game up.  You won't be dissapointed!!!

description: Resident Evil 4 Wii
summary: Excellent Wii Release for Easier Gameplay
reviewText: I originally owned Resident Evil 4 for the Gamecube and I was frustrated with the cumbersome sights and aiming mechanism and poor reaction time limited by the controller.  Enter the Nintendo Wii remote.Obviously you're allowed to aim with the Wii remote as the ubiquitous laser sight is replaced with an ever-present cross hair.  This allows for considerably better accuracy and reaction time.  My first time through my accuracy was around 75% (I know, I'm a terrible person) and my reaction time was pitiful.  With the Wii edition my accuracy went up to 90% and better reaction time.  The downside is the cross hair is always there and can be slightly annoying; I think the laser sighting would've been more appropriate and only present when aiming.  Another downside is you cannot aim scoped weapons (rifles and launchers) with the Wii remote, but with the nunchuck.  It might be better to have allowed aiming with the Wii remote similar to Call of Duty 3 but that's my preference.Pertaining to the gameplay and graphics they're almost no different than the PSXII or Gamecube version; if there is a difference I certainly didn't notice it.  Don't let this deter you as the gameplay makes up for that and if you're like me and started with the Gamecube version, you get all the bonuses of the PSXII version only you can aim better.  You get the five chapters of Separate Ways (Ada's quest), the special costume 2 set (mafia outfit and Thompson for Leon and the suit of armor for Ashley (annoying to hear but boy it comes in handy A LOT in the castle).Lastly, there's one Wii exclusive element and that is the trailer for Resident Evil: The Umbrella Chronicles... and there was much rejoicing (Monty Python "yay").  Not much cool stuff for the Wii but oh well.  The release price, however, sets it apart from other Wii titles to the point where it's cheaper than most to purchase.Overall RE4 for Wii is worth purchasing if you're a Wii owner; it improves your game and you can still enjoy the classic arcade blowing heads off spree.  Wheee!

description: Bionic Commando is back, now on the PS3, 20 years after the NES classic was initially released. Bionic Commando makes the move to 3D, and gamers will be able to grapple, swing, and scale a giant environment filled with buildings, canyons, and more..caption { font-family: Verdana, Helvetica neue, Arial, serif; font-size: 10px; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic; } ul.indent { list-style: inside disc; text-indent: -15px; } table.callout { font-family: verdana; font-size: 11px; line-height: 1. 3em; } td.vgoverview { height: 125px; background: #9DC4D8 url(http://images.amazon.com/images/G/01/electronics/detail-page/callout-bg.png) repeat-x; border-left: 1px solid #999999; border-right: 1px solid #999999; padding-left: 20px; padding-right: 20px; padding-bottom: 10px; width: 250px; font-family: verdana; font-size: 12px; } img.withlink {border:1px #777777 solid;}There are many creative uses for your bionic arm.View larger.Being able to swing and shoot is an essential skill.View larger.Freely explore Ascension City and its outskirts.View larger.Ten players can get it on the action at the same time.View larger.Nathan Spencer is BackBionic Commando takes place 10 years after the 1988 game, with Nathan Spencer again the protagonist. Voiced by Mike Patton, ex-Faith No More singer, Spencer is betrayed by his government, falsely accused of murder and sentenced to execution. Just prior to his execution, however, the city is bombed and Spencer is asked to track down the terrorists in return for his freedom.Bionic Arm Offers New Control PossibilitiesLike in the original game, the bionic arm is what separates Bionic Commando from other games. With it, you can swing between buildings, grapple onto ledges and zip up, walk walls, pull apart the landscape, throw heavy objects, attack enemies, and more.Giant, Sweeping World to ExploreAs you swing around with your bionic arm, you'll be subjected to beautifully detailed scenery that ranges from Ascension City and its bridges and skyscrapers, to outdoor environments like canyons. If you misjudge your swing by even a little bit, you might find yourself plunging to your doom.Swinging Multiplayer Fun for up to Ten PlayersBionic Commando allows up to 10 players at a time to get in on the swinging fun, finding new ways and techniques with the bionic arm to dispatch your friends and enemies. Maps are designed with the swing and gun game mechanic in mind, rewarding players who are adept at simultaneously swinging and aiming.Bionic Commando is an updated and beautiful take on the classic, bringing the core elements of the 8-bit original into a beautiful, 3D world. Fans of the classic and newcomers alike will delight at the unique game play options that the bionic arm afford.

reviewText: Summary:Pos-1. Great stealth type gameplay (if your into that)2. Quite challenging if you want to make it through the game without killing anyone. (can also be a con)3. Story is interesting.4. Characters are different.5. A bit of a bioshock feel to it. (could also be a con)6. Not afraid to be a new story.7. It went on slightly longer then I expected.Cons-1. It kinda takes a few things from other games.2. It might not allow for a sequel.3. You have to work your bum off in order to get the good ending it seems like.4. The story can become predictable after a certain point.Detailed summary:I got interested in this game right when I saw the mask on the cover. I had heard about it a bit here and there when it was first being teased. I kept it on my radar but didn't pay to much attention to it at first. Then later on after the price had gone down I payed a bit more attention to it and saw it looked quite fun so I got it.If any of you have seen game play trailers and such you can already spot that the game takes a few ideas from other games. That isn't always a bad thing but just something worth noting.I found the story to be slightly interesting (maybe not the best but still pretty good). Near the middle of the game though it can be slightly predictable what is going to happen.You are stuck with 2 main weapons. You get a sword and a crossbow/pistol for weapons. You do get to switch out the sword for special powers however they are only a few extra ones and they are limited by how much (mana?) you have. Some of the powers are fun but in order to upgrade them all the way or get enough variety you need to go find these special things.The main way I played was stealthy. The other ways could be quite difficult at times. I have found though that sometimes it felt like there really was no way to bypass certain areas just doing stealth. And with certain stealth areas you would have to wait, studying the routes the guards/enemies go over and over again just to find the best spot to go through or strike.There was little secrets and cool places to go around but for the most part there were only a handful of buildings you could actually go in, in this game. Each level had a few where you could only go in one room and out through the other window. That is a minor problem though.And for the story at one point I felt I was getting close to the end but was surprised to find it kept going a bit longer.One character in particular is one I would like them to go into more detail with if they make more games which is the man you receive your powers from. He is someone who you can be unsure of and also mesmerized by. That kind of quality isn't found often and when you do it seems like it doesn't last long before you lose that character.One con that was quite annoying at the end of the game was that there is some ways you have to play in order to get the very good ending. There appears to be three endings. A good, a neutral, and a bad ending. I killed a few guards near the beginning of the game unaware of how to bypass them and that I should try not to kill them but for most of the game I only knocked out the enemies yet I ended up with an evil ending it seemed. I was quite annoyed by that. The only way to figure it out is if you get lucky or look it up online on how to get the certain endings and its still somewhat criptic. It appears you have to be less "chaotic" or something like that to get the good ending. Although a lot of online guides don't expand on what that means. So even with trying not to kill all the guards/enemies you can still end up with the ending you don't desire.All in all it was a fun game. Although it felt like it didn't leave much room for a sequel at least not with the main characters. It wrapped it all up in the last scenes which is a shame. I expect they will make a sequel but it will be a completely different character.I would say its fun and you should give it a try if you like what you see in the trailers and pictures. It can be quite challenging from a stealth standpoint. I hope this review has helped at least one person in their decision on this game.
